<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 209]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 388, 233]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 455, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 327, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 433]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 448, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 495]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
It is known that \(1.2\%\) of rods made by a certain machine are bent. The random variable \(X\) denotes the number of bent rods in a random sample of 400 rods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 154, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 371, 138]]<|/det|>
State the distribution of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 151, 153, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 151, 655, 170]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, a suitable approximate distribution for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 153, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 183, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
Use your approximate distribution to find the probability that the sample will include more than 2 bent rods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 199, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 244, 97, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 243, 620, 262]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 271, 603, 320]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{2}{3} x & 1\leqslant x\leqslant 2,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 336, 248, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 336, 248, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>Find</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 336, 248, 354]]<|/det|>
E(X).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 367, 151, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 367, 311, 384]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X < \mathrm{E}(X))\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 367, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 148, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 396, 923, 415]]<|/det|>
Hence explain whether the mean of \(X\) is less than, equal to or greater than the median of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 444, 94, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
The heights of a certain variety of plant have been found to be normally distributed with mean \(75.2 \mathrm{~cm}\) and standard deviation \(5.7 \mathrm{~cm}\). A biologist suspects that pollution in a certain region is causing the plants to be shorter than usual. He takes a random sample of \(n\) plants of this variety from this region and finds that their mean height is \(73.1 \mathrm{~cm}\). He then carries out an appropriate hypothesis test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 523, 151, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 523, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
He finds that the value of the test statistic \(z\) is \(- 1.563\), correct to 3 decimal places. Calculate the value of \(n\). State an assumption necessary for your calculation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 537, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 568, 153, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 567, 898, 586]]<|/det|>
Use this value of the test statistic to carry out the hypothesis test at the \(6\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 630, 94, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
The masses, in grams, of a certain type of plum are normally distributed with mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma^2\). The masses, \(m\) grams, of a random sample of 150 plums of this type were found and the results are summarised by \(\Sigma m = 9750\) and \(\Sigma m^2 = 647500\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 694, 153, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 694, 490, 712]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of \(\mu\) and \(\sigma^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 694, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 725, 153, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 725, 499, 744]]<|/det|>
Calculate a \(98\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 725, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 756, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
Two more random samples of plums of this type are taken and a \(98\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\) is calculated from each sample.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 803, 148, 821]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 803, 680, 821]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that neither of these two intervals contains \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 803, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Packets of cereal are packed in boxes, each containing 6 packets. The masses of the packets are normally distributed with mean \(510\mathrm{g}\) and standard deviation \(12\mathrm{g}\). The masses of the empty boxes are normally distributed with mean \(70\mathrm{g}\) and standard deviation \(4\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total mass of a full box containing 6 packets is between \(3050\mathrm{g}\) and \(3150\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[88, 183, 118, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 183, 920, 216]]<|/det|>
A packet and an empty box are chosen at random. Find the probability that the mass of the packet is at least 8 times the mass of the empty box.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 201, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 244, 96, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 244, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
The number of cases of asthma per month at a clinic has a Poisson distribution. In the past the mean has been 5.3 cases per month. A new treatment is introduced. In order to test at the \(5\%\) significance level whether the mean has decreased, the number of cases in a randomly chosen month is noted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 306, 153, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 306, 898, 325]]<|/det|>
Find the critical region for the test and, given that the number of cases is 2, carry out the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 322, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 352, 151, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 352, 915, 371]]<|/det|>
Explain the meaning of a Type I error in this context and state the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 368, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 151, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
At another clinic the mean number of cases of asthma per month has the independent distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(13.1)\). Assuming that the mean for the first clinic is still 5.3, use a suitable approximating distribution to estimate the probability that the total number of cases in the two clinics in a particular month is more than 20.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 445, 920, 464]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
# BLANK PAGE
